intro: Bolina conferta, commonly known as the New Zealand flax, is a flowering plant native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Asphodelaceae and is characterized by its tall, narrow leaves that can grow up to several meters in length. The plant produces small, greenish-white flowers arranged in dense clusters at the ends of its stems. Bolina conferta is often cultivated for its ornamental value and has historical significance in Māori culture. Its fibrous leaves were traditionally used to make textiles and other crafts.
